facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 760 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 760 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 16, 1959 of Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 1123 of 1956.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1123 of 1956 filed in Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 1123 of 1956. R. Chaudhuri, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition questioning validity of s. 11(2) of Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, No. XIV of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court questioning the validity of s. 11  2  of the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, No. XIV of 1950,  hereinafter referred

facts.text: Appellant acted as agent in the then State of Hyderabad to both resident and non-resident principals for sale of betel leaves.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts on which the petition was based were these. The appellant acted as agent in the then State of Hyderabad to both resident and number-resident principals

facts.text: Betel leaves were taxable at the purchase point from May 1, 1953 by virtue of a notification.

anchor.surface_text: in regard to sale of betel leaves. Under the Act betel leaves were taxable at the purchase point from May 1, 1953, by virtue of a numberification in that behalf.

facts.text: Assessment period from May 1, 1953 to March 31, 1954 for assessment year 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: We are here companycerned with the assessment period from May 1, 1953 to March 31, 1954, companyered by the assessment year 1953-54.

facts.text: Appellant collected sales tax from purchasers assuming incident of tax on sellers and assured no further liability.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companylected sales tax from the purchasers in companynection with the sales made by it on the basis that the incident of the tax lay on the sellers and assured the purchasers

facts.text: Appellant did not pay collected tax to Government but kept it in suspense account of its principals, namely the purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: that after paying the tax to the appellant, there would be numberfurther liability on them. After realising the tax, however, the appellant did number pay the amount realised

facts.text: Sales Tax Department scrutinized accounts and discovered non-payment.

anchor.surface_text: to the Government but kept it in the suspense account of its principals, namely, the purchasers. When the accounts were scrutinized by the Sales Tax Department, this was discovered

facts.text: Sales Tax Department called upon appellant to pay amounts realised to Government.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the appellant was called upon to pay the amounts realised to the Government. The appellant however objected to the payment on the ground

facts.text: Appellant objected to payment claiming it was the seller and tax imposed at purchase point on purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant however objected to the payment on the ground that it was the seller and the relevant numberification for the relevant period imposed tax at the purchase point,

facts.text: Objection overruled and appellant directed to pay amount to Government.

anchor.surface_text: i.e. on the purchaser. This objection was over-ruled and the appellant was directed to pay the amount to Government.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the writ petition was dismissed. The High Court having refused a certificate to appeal to this Court,

facts.text: High Court refused certificate to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused a certificate to appeal to this Court, the appellant obtained special leave

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant obtained special leave and that is how the matter has companye up be-fore us.

facts.text: Appellant is a registered dealer.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on February 21, 1964 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: February 21, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO j.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer issued final assessment order dated September 27, 1956 based on s.11(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed, as appears from the final assessment order of the Sales Tax Officer, that the appellant was number liable

facts.text: Appellant was not liable to pay the amount as sales tax for the relevant period, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed, as appears from the final assessment order of the Sales Tax Officer, that the appellant was number liable to pay the amount as sales tax for the relevant period.

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed assessment order dated September 27, 1956 insofar as based on s.11(2).

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and quash the assessment order dated September 27, 1956 insofar as it is based on s. II  2 .

facts.text: Case concerns collections after May 1, 1950.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 1123 of 1956.
The High Court having refused a certificate to appeal to this Court, the appellant obtained special leave and that is how the matter has come up be-fore us.
The appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court questioning the validity of s. 11  2  of the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, No. XIV of 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

Now there is no dispute that the heads of legislation in the various Lists in the Seventh Schedule should be interpreted widely so as to take in all matters which are of a character incidental to the topics mentioned therein. Even so, there is a limit to such incidental or ancillary power flowing from the legislative entries

arguments.claim: s. 11(2) of the Act was beyond the legislative competence of the State legislature under Entry 54 of List II as it authorises recovery of amounts collected by way of tax otherwise than in accordance with the Act which are not exigible as tax

anchor.surface_text: The main contention raised on behalf of the appellant in the High Court was that s. 11  2  of the Act, which authorised the Government to recover from any person, who had collected or collects, after May 1, 1950, any amount by way of tax otherwise than in accordance with .he provisions of the Act, as arrears of land revenue, was beyond the legislative competence of the State legislature. The argument was that the Act was passed under Entry 54 of List 11 of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution, which enables the State legislature to enact a law taxing transactions of sale or purchase of goods.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: idental and ancillary powers have to be exercised in aid of the main topic of legislation, which in the present case, is a tax on sale or purchase of

arguments.court_reasoning: Incidental and ancillary powers under Entry 54 are limited to levy, collection, and prevention of evasion of exigible tax; do not extend to recovery of non-exigible amounts collected as tax

arguments.claim: s. 11(2) is valid as an ancillary provision with regard to the collection of sales or purchase tax and therefore incidental to the taxing power under Entry 54 of List II

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held s. 11  2  good as an ancillary provision with regard to the collection of sales or purchase tax and therefore incidental to the taxing power under Entry 54 of List 11.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: idental and ancillary powers have to be exercised in aid of the main topic of legislation, which in the present case, is a tax on sale or purchase of

arguments.court_reasoning: Ancillary power must aid levy and collection of exigible tax; s.11(2) deals with non-exigible amounts mistaken for tax

arguments.claim: Assuming Entry 54 of List II could not sustain s. 11(2), it could be sustained under Entry 26 of List II

anchor.surface_text: Further the High Court took the view that assuming that Entry 54 of List II could not sustain s. 11  2 , it could be sustained under Entry 26 of List H.

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 26 deals with trade and commerce, separate from taxing entries; no element of regulation of trade and commerce in s.11(2)

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made to justify the provision as providing for a penalty. But as we read s. 11  2  we cannot find anything in it to justify that it is a penalty

arguments.court_reasoning: No indication of penalty for breach; penalties in tax statutes for evasion or default on properly levied taxes; s.20 provides separate penalties

arguments.claim: s. 11(2) is within the legislative competence of the State legislature in view of Entry 26 of List II as it regulates trade and commerce
arguments.court_reasoning: Taxing entries separate from trade and commerce; s.11(2) has no element of regulation of trade and commerce

arguments.claim: Incidental and ancillary powers under Entry 54 of List II do not extend to recovery of amounts collected by way of tax though not exigible as tax under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Now there is no dispute that the heads of legislation in the various Lists in the Seventh Schedule should be interpreted widely so as to take in all matters which are of a character incidental to the topics mentioned therein. Even so, there is a limit to such incidental or ancillary power flowing from the legislative entries

arguments.claim: s.11(2) distinguished from Orient Paper Mills case as that dealt with refund of exigible tax while s.11(2) requires payment of non-exigible amounts

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in this connection relies on the decision of this Court in The Orient Paper Mills Limited v. The State of Orissa . That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of the present case.

arguments.claim: s.20(c) falls with s.11(2) as consequential

holdings.text: The provision contained in s. 11(2) cannot be made under Entry 54 of List II and cannot be justified even as an incidental or ancillary provision permitted under that entry.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the provision contained in s. 11  2  cannot be made under Entry 54 of List 11 and cannot be justified even as an incidental or ancillary provision permitted under that entry. An attempt was made to justify the provision as providing for a penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incidental and ancillary powers under taxing entry limited to levy, collection, and prevention of evasion of exigible tax; does not extend to compelling payment of non-exigible amounts collected as tax.

holdings.text: s. 11(2) cannot be justified as providing for a penalty.

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made to justify the provision as providing for a penalty. But as we read s. 11  2  we cannot find anything in it to justify that it is a penalty for breach of any prohibition in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual indication of penalty; penalties in tax statutes address evasion or default on properly levied taxes; separate penalty provisions exist in ss.19-20.

holdings.text: s.11(2) is not within the competence of the State legislature under Entry 54 of List II.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that s.11  2  is number within the competence of the State legislature under Entry 54 of List II.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot directly or indirectly (via incidental powers or penalty guise) authorize recovery of non-exigible tax collections as it is not a tax on sale/purchase.

holdings.text: The decision in Orient Paper Mills Limited v. State of Orissa has no application to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in this connection relies on the decision of this Court in The Orient Paper Mills Limited v. The State of Orissa . That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orient dealt with refund of exigible tax under incidental powers; here s.11(2) mandates payment of non-exigible amounts to government.

holdings.text: s.11(2) is not within the legislative competence under Entry 26 of List II.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the State legislature was Incompetent to enact a provision like s. 11  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxing entries separate from trade/commerce; s.11(2) lacks any element of regulating trade and commerce.

holdings.text: The provision contained in s.20(c), being consequential to s.11(2), will fall along with it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.20(c) penalizes failure to comply with invalid s.11(2); invalidity consequential.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; assessment order dated September 27, 1956 quashed insofar as based on s.11(2).

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and quash the assessment order dated September 27, 1956 insofar as it is based on s. II  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.11(2) ultra vires; appellant not liable to pay collected amounts as tax under the Act.
